issuetype.description: A new feature of the product, which has yet to be developed.
issuetype.name: New Feature

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: A user story. Created by JIRA Software - do not edit or delete.
issuetype.name: Story

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
Mitch:

  
Vika reported a problem with "euare-useraddcert" parameters. Basically, there
are two parameters for the command that you have to pick either one of them
and you must pick one: the certificate body (either as a file or as a inline
text string). Right now we set both of them as "optional". Then if you don't
provide a cert when invoking the command, the request will fail because the
binding process looks for a certificate body parameter in the request, which
results a weird error (412: precondition failed). I'm wondering if we support
a parameter type that basically you need to pick one from multiple choices.
This is not critical but still important.
fields.summary: support "pick one from multiple alternatives" parameters

comments.body:
Originally posted on 2011-11-11 23:40:30 by wenye

Fri Nov 11 15:40:30 2011: Request 4518 was acted upon.
 Transaction: Ticket created by wen.ye
       Queue: Engineering Bugs
     Subject: euca2ools: support "pick one from multiple alternatives" parameters
       Owner: mitch.garnaat
  Requestors: wenye@eucalyptus.com
      Status: new
 Ticket <URL: https://support.eucalyptus.com/Ticket/Display.html?id=4518 >


Mitch:

Vika reported a problem with "euare-useraddcert" parameters. Basically, there
are two parameters for the command that you have to pick either one of them and
you must pick one: the certificate body (either as a file or as a inline text
string). Right now we set both of them as "optional". Then if you don't provide
a cert when invoking the command, the request will fail because the binding
process looks for a certificate body parameter in the request, which results a
weird error (412: precondition failed). I'm wondering if we support a parameter
type that basically you need to pick one from multiple choices. This is not
critical but still important.

Originally posted on 2011-11-14 03:38:33 by admin
I've thought about adding this.  I think it would be useful and not very
difficult.  It would require a small change in the boto/roboto code and
then some edits to the Params declarations for the affected commands.  I'll
go ahead and do this in a branch and we can decide whether to do it for 3.0
in the bug scrub.


On Fri, Nov 11, 2011 at 6:40 PM, Ye Wen via RT
<bugs@support.eucalyptus.com>wrote:

> type that basically you need to pick one from multiple choices. This is not
> critical but still important.
>

I'll go ahead and do this in a branch and we can decide whether to do it for 3.0 in the bug scrub.

Ticket https://support.eucalyptus.com/Ticket/Display.html?id=4518 >


Mitch:

Vika reported a problem with "euare-useraddcert" parameters. Basically, there
are two parameters for the command that you have to pick either one of them and
you must pick one: the certificate body (either as a file or as a inline text
string). Right now we set both of them as "optional". Then if you don't provide
a cert when invoking the command, the request will fail because the binding
process looks for a certificate body parameter in the request, which results a
weird error (412: precondition failed). I'm wondering if we support a parameter
type that basically you need to pick one from multiple choices. This is not
critical but still important.

Fixed with requestbuilder.  See {{euare-useraddcert}}'s {{-c}} and {{-f}} options as well as {{euca-authorize}}'s {{-s}} and {{-o}} options for examples of "pick one of N" and "pick up to one of N" options, respectively.
